key_points: El Paso experienced minimal disruptions from a historic winter storm, contrasting with the rest of Texas which faced severe power outages.
Robert Gomez, an El Paso resident, found local stores fully stocked and utilities functioning, unlike in other Texas cities.
El Paso's preparation for winter storms, following a 2011 storm, and its connection to the Western Interconnection grid helped it avoid power outages.
The Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT) manages about 90% of Texas's electric load but couldn't draw power from other states during the storm.
El Paso Electric spent millions on winterizing its facilities, including the construction of the Montana Power Station with dual-fuel capability.
Many Texas power companies ignored voluntary winterization guidelines issued by ERCOT following the 2011 outages.
El Paso Electric's participation in the Western Interconnection incentivizes winterization for selling excess energy out-of-state.
Calls for mandatory winterization in Texas have risen, with responsibility falling on state legislators and agencies.
Experts are divided on the best approach to avoid future outages, with some suggesting policy change rather than altering market rules.
Despite El Paso's resilience, the widespread suffering in Texas highlights systemic failures in policy and planning.
spokespersons: Steve Buraczyk (Senior Vice President of Operations, El Paso Electric)
Ramanan Krishnamoorti (Chief Energy Officer, University of Houston)
Carey King (Assistant Director, University of Texas's Energy Institute)
